awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Biomedical Engineering in Simulations, Imaging, and Modeling (BME-SIM)
awd_abstract_narration:
This Biomedical Engineering in Simulations, Imaging, and Modeling (BME-SIM) Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site, at East Carolina University (ECU), will provide high quality research experiences to undergraduate students, specifically targeting women, underrepresented minorities, and students whose home institutions provide limited opportunities for research. The educational goals of this REU will be accomplished through a multidisciplinary approach using simulations, imaging, and modeling as a common thread. The popularity of computational research models has increased due to limited use of human subjects and animals.  Furthermore, as the trend towards personalized medicine spurs the development and refinement of models across scales from cells, to organs, to entire systems, multiscale modeling is becoming integrated into clinical decision support. Exposing REU students to innovative research will increase their awareness about graduate school and ultimately increase the STEM graduate school pipeline. The proposed REU program will also strengthen their STEM career paths and increase student's identities as scientists or engineers, and improve their communication skills. The student research projects have the potential to substantially improve the development of models in biomedical engineering which will reduce reliance on human and animal data, and expedite innovation. These models will have many different applications, for example: calculating loads acting on the human body during movement, simulating tasks that cannot safely be performed by experimental subjects, and simulating blood flow through vessels. Additional benefits from this program include improved connections to faculty at ECU partner institutions. Through the REU program students will be exposed to cutting edge research utilizing advanced computational models with applications in biomedical engineering.

The goal of the BME-SIM program is to provide a quality research experience to students, especially those who have limited opportunities for research at their home institution or come from groups underrepresented in science and engineering. At the end of the program students should have a better understanding of how to conduct research, increased awareness of graduate school, clarification and reinforcement of STEM career path, and greater identification as engineer/scientist. Additionally, a new focus of this program will provide training to improve students' communication skills. To achieve these program goals participants will be engaged for longer than the 10 week summer research experience by collaborating with home institution mentors. To ensure a broad applicant pool, student recruitment will begin at ECU partner institutions which include several regional HBCUs and community colleges which serve underrepresented minority, veteran and low-socioeconomic status student populations. Graduates of the program will gain a better understanding of graduate school and be competitive in the graduate school application process increasing diversity in the STEM pipeline.

por.por_cntn:
Quality undergraduate research experiences improve the educational experience of students and increase the likelihood of pursuing graduate degrees in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math). However, many students do not have access to authentic research opportunities at their home institution. This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) award supported training and development of 30 students.  The focus of the research projects was on the integration of imaging and modeling, giving students skills needed for competitive graduate school applications and in the STEM workforce.  While the highlight of the student experience was the research project, students also received valuable professional development training including a series on oral and written communication. Students built mentoring relationships with REU faculty, home institution mentors, and the other REU students that often continues long after the program ends.   

Intellectual Merit

In addition to providing educational experiences, it was also the goal of this program to conduct impactful research and share these results with the scientific community. The research from this award resulted in five peer-reviewed research articles and 58 research conference presentations.  The large majority of the conference presentations were presented by the REU students and most at national level conferences. The results from these research projects have advanced the state of knowledge in several areas. For example: One project determined vertical stiffness and leg stiffness during hopping can be reasonably predicted using high speed 2D video and open-source software compared to 3D motion capture and analysis. Another project used magnetic resonance imaging to investigate age-related trends regarding normal adenoid development across the age span. The work confirmed the existence of an adenoid growth curve trend and provided a more definitive point of adenoid maturation. The results may be used in the future to assess adenoid growth in subjects with cleft palate or other disorders. Another project developed and tested a virtual reality eye tracking test as a portable means for detection of traumatic brain injury. The preliminary results identified some parameters that varied between those with concussions and those without.  

In addition to research on biomechanics, simulations, imaging, and modeling, we also conducted research on the effectiveness of our research program. The evaluation results of our program were published in the Journal of Biomechanical Engineering, and best practices on program development and execution have been shared through conference presentations.  We also published on gender differences in application personal statements of those accepted into the program.

Broader Impacts

Our program was successful at encouraging graduate school enrollment for our alumni. Of the 30 participants, all have graduated with their undergraduate degree. Of those who have graduated, 19 (63%, 8 of whom come from underrepresented racial and/or ethnic backgrounds and 10 of whom are women) have enrolled in graduate programs (11 MS, 7 PhD, 3 Professional). Of the 7 students who have completed their graduate program, most are working in industry.

We used a unique strategy in our program recruitment, including partnerships with several regional universities, to encourage diverse participation and specifically target under-represented populations.  Many of our students are from populations that have traditionally been underrepresented in science and engineering. Fifty percent of our participants were from underrepresented minorities and 50% were women.  Our program was also successful in encouraging participation among students from institutions with traditionally limited research opportunities. The large majority (83%) of our students came from institutions with limited research opportunities.

In addition to providing a diverse group of students with research experiences and successful graduate enrollment rates, we have disseminated best practices, including mentoring and recruitment strategies, to the educational community through publications and presentations.
